absent = 4
absent = 4

absent = (hat@(f _ 1) tensor-product hat@(f _ 2)) * open-interval@(xi _ 1, xi _ 2)

para.p: showing that the Fourier transform of a tensor product is the tensor product of the Fourier transforms.

section.title: 3Approximate identities and Bernstein’s inequality for 𝕋

para.p:
An approximate identity is a sequence
k N
in
⁢
L ∞
(
T d
)
such that (i)
<
sup N
∥
k N
∥
1
∞
, (ii) for each
N
,

Math.text: (integral _ (T ^ d))@(k _ N * x * differential-d@(lambda _ d) * x) = 1

para.p:
and (iii) for each
0 < δ <
1 2
,

Math.text: (limit _ (n to infinity))@((integral _ (delta less= x less= 1 - delta))@(absolute-value@(k _ N * x) * differential-d@(lambda _ d) * x)) = 0

A trigonometric polynomial is a function
: P
→
T d
C
of the form

Math.text: formulae@(P * x = (sum _ (xi element-of Z ^ d))@(a _ xi * e ^ ((2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x)), x element-of T ^ d)

for which there is some
≥ N 0
such that

N

P

N

P

N
then

M
for each

∈ f

( T )

We define the Dirichlet kernel
:
D N

para.p:
We define the Fejér kernel
∈
F N
⁢ C
( T )
by
We can write the Fejér kernel as

Math.text: F _ N * x = (sum _ (absolute-value@(j) less= N))@((1 - absolute-value@(j) / (N + 1)) * e ^ (2 * pi * i * j * x)) = (sum _ (j element-of Z))@(chi _ (closed-interval@(- N, N)) * j * (1 - absolute-value@(j) / (N + 1)) * e ^ (2 * pi * i * j * x))

para.p:
where
χ A
is the indicator function of the set
A
. It is straightforward to prove that
F N
is an approximate identity.

We define the
d
-dimensional Fejér kernel
∈
F
N , d
⁢ C
(
T d
)
by

Math.text: F _ (list@(N, d)) = (underbrace@(F _ N tensor-product cdots tensor-product F _ N)) _ d

para.p:
We can write
F
N , d
as

Math.text: formulae@(F _ (list@(N, d)) * x = (sum _ ((absolute-value@(xi)) _ infinity less= N))@((1 - absolute-value@(xi _ 1) / (N + 1)) * cdots * (1 - absolute-value@(xi _ d) / (N + 1)) * e ^ ((2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x)), x element-of T ^ d)

para.p:
Using the fact that
F N
is an approximate identity on
T
, one proves that
F
N , d
is an approximate identity on
T d
.

The following is Bernstein’s inequality for
T
.

p.text:
If
P
is a trigonometric polynomial of degree
N
, then

Math.text: (norm@(P ^ prime)) _ infinity less= 4 * pi * N * (norm@(P)) _ infinity

para.p: Define

The Fourier transform of the first term on the right-hand side is, for
∈ j Z
,

Math.text: widehat@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1)) * widehat@(e _ N) * j = (sum _ (k element-of Z))@(widehat@(e _ (- N) * P) * (j - k) * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - k) * widehat@(e _ N) * k)
widehat@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1)) * widehat@(e _ N) * j
absent = (sum _ (k element-of Z))@(widehat@(e _ (- N) * P) * (j - k) * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - k) * widehat@(e _ N) * k)
absent = widehat@(e _ (- N) * P) * (j - N) * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N)
absent = widehat@(e _ (- N) * P) * (j - N) * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N)
absent = widehat@(P) * j * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N)
absent = widehat@(P) * j * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N)

para.p: and the Fourier transform of the second term is

Math.text: widehat@(P) * j * widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j + N)

para.p:
Therefore, for
∈ j Z
, using
=
^ P
⁢
χ
[
- N
, N ]
^ P
,

Math.text: widehat@(Q) * j = widehat@(P) * j * (widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N) - widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j + N))
widehat@(Q) * j
absent = widehat@(P) * j * (widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j - N) - widehat@(F _ (N - 1)) * (j + N))
absent = widehat@(P) * j * (chi _ (closed-interval@((- N) + 1, N - 1)) * (j - N) * (1 - absolute-value@(j - N) / N) - chi _ (closed-interval@((- N) + 1, N - 1)) * (1 - absolute-value@(j + N) / N))
absent = widehat@(P) * j * (chi _ (closed-interval@((- N) + 1, N - 1)) * (j - N) * (1 - absolute-value@(j - N) / N) - chi _ (closed-interval@((- N) + 1, N - 1)) * (1 - absolute-value@(j + N) / N))
absent = widehat@(P) * j * (chi _ (closed-interval@(1, N)) * j * (1 + (j - N) / N) - chi _ (closed-interval@(- N, - 1)) * j * (1 - (j + N) / N))
absent = widehat@(P) * j * (chi _ (closed-interval@(1, N)) * j * (1 + (j - N) / N) - chi _ (closed-interval@(- N, - 1)) * j * (1 - (j + N) / N))
absent = widehat@(P) * j * ((j / N) * chi _ (closed-interval@(1, N)) * j + (j / N) * chi _ (closed-interval@(- N, - 1)) * j)
absent = widehat@(P) * j * ((j / N) * chi _ (closed-interval@(1, N)) * j + (j / N) * chi _ (closed-interval@(- N, - 1)) * j)
absent = (j / N) * widehat@(P) * j
absent = (j / N) * widehat@(P) * j

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: widehat@(P ^ prime) * j = 2 * pi * i * j * widehat@(P) * j

para.p: so that

Math.text: P ^ prime = 2 * pi * i * N * Q

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: P ^ prime = 2 * pi * i * N * (e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ N - e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ (- N))

para.p: Then, by Young’s inequality,

Math.text: (norm@(P ^ prime)) _ infinity = 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ N - e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ (- N))) _ infinity
(norm@(P ^ prime)) _ infinity
absent = 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ N - e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ (- N))) _ infinity
absent less= 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ N)) _ infinity + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ (- N))) _ infinity
absent less= 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ N)) _ infinity + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1) * e _ (- N))) _ infinity
absent = 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1))) _ infinity + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1))) _ infinity
absent = 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P * F _ (N - 1))) _ infinity + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P * F _ (N - 1))) _ infinity
absent less= 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P)) _ infinity * (norm@(F _ (N - 1))) _ 1 + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P)) _ infinity * (norm@(F _ (N - 1))) _ 1
absent less= 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ (- N) * P)) _ infinity * (norm@(F _ (N - 1))) _ 1 + 2 * pi * N * (norm@(e _ N * P)) _ infinity * (norm@(F _ (N - 1))) _ 1
absent = 4 * pi * N * (norm@(P)) _ infinity
absent = 4 * pi * N * (norm@(P)) _ infinity
